Art History and Visual Culture

Degree

Bachelor of Arts

School

Arts and Communication

Department

Art and Art History

Program at a Glance

Get inspired and cultivate a practical foundation for life in the arts. Our programs develop both conceptual and technical abilities, so you can tap your full potential in creative thinking, artistic expression, problem-solving, and scholarly research. You’ll also get to experience the renowned art scenes of nearby Philadelphia and New York City. Graduates of our programs go on to study in top graduate programs or pursue rewarding careers with a range of employers. TCNJ also offers BFA programs in fine art and photography and video.

ApplyRequest Info

Minors

Art History and Visual Culture Minor

Fine Art Minor

Photography and Video Minor

Students benefit from:

  • Small, collaborative classes with personalized instruction
  • Challenging, contemporary curriculum with experiential learning
  • Opportunities for internships, exhibitions, performances, and publishing
  • Access to cutting-edge technology, NYC and Philadelphia arts, and study abroad
  • Flexible curriculum and opportunities for a dual or self-designed major
  • Instruction and mentorship from a renowned faculty of artist-teachers

Careers

Our graduates have the skills, insight, and experience to succeed in a range of careers and enter top graduate programs. Recent TCNJ graduates have launched vibrant careers with employers that include major corporations, museums, galleries, and communication companies. Other graduates are pursuing MAs and PhDs in Art History, Museum Studies, Library Science, Art Criticism, the History of Decorative Arts, Arts Management, Visual Arts Administration, and Art Museum Education.

Capstone

The art history curriculum culminates in a two-semester capstone sequence during which majors develop an original research project to demonstrate their critical thinking and writing skills.

Experiential Learning

Art and art history students can exercise their skills and talents, pursue their interests, and gain real-world, hands-on experience beyond the classroom. You’ll be encouraged to apply for local internships in Philadelphia and New York City that enrich your academic and professional portfolios. Students may also participate in faculty-led study tours to destinations such as Cuba, India, Greece, London, and France — or complete a longer study-abroad academic program. Dynamic, student-led organizations like the Rebel Art Movement and Kappa Pi also invite involvement and foster community engagement in the arts on and off campus. Our programs empower you to master your craft while grounding your work in theory and analysis of visual culture. 

Regional and National Museums TCNJ Engages With

  • Grounds for Sculpture and the International Sculpture Center
  • The Philadelphia Museum of Art
  • Princeton Art Museum
  • Museum of Modern Art
  • The Frick Collection
  • Newark Museum
  • The New Jersey State Museum 
  • The Rubin Museum
  • The Metropolitan Museum of Art

State-of-the-Art Facilities

Students create, contemplate, and curate art in our 70,000-square-foot Art and Interactive Multimedia Building. It’s home to drawing, painting, and printmaking studios as well as a wood shop, plaster area, metal fabrication area, ceramics area, digital arts labs and studios, photography studios, and student exhibition space. The AIMM Building also houses the TCNJ Art Gallery and Makerspace.

Study Abroad

Art History and Visual Culture majors are encouraged to enroll in a study-abroad program to promote cross-cultural exchange and exposure to art outside the area. TCNJ offers many options ranging from a three-week study-abroad course to full-semester or year-long programs. To graduate with a BA degree in Art History and Visual Culture, students must complete an approved study abroad or internship experience.

Competitive Scholarship Opportunities
